Introduction
Praise be to Allah who sent His Messenger with guidance and the religion of truth to manifest it over all religion, although those who associate others with Allah dislike it. I bear witness that there is no deity but Allah alone, with no partner, and I bear witness that Muhammad is His servant and Messenger, the seal of the prophets and messengers, may Allah bless him and his family and all his companions and those who follow them in goodness until the Day of Judgment. To proceed.
The study of religious science, its importance and Sharia regulations, the methodologies of researchers in it in the past and present, and the clarification of the true methodology in terms of reception, inference, and presentation, are among the topics related to the Creed (Aqeedah) that should be given attention. "The importance of writing on this subject comes from the danger of those misguided religions and deviant, destructive sects and trends to Muslims and humanity as a whole. And because a Muslim must be highly aware, vigilant, and concerned about his religion and his nation, and knowledgeable and insightful about the opinions, methodologies, and misguided trends revolving around him that are storming Muslims and all of humanity, to be the best caller to guidance and the best savior from misguidance. The conflict between truth and falsehood is Allah's way in His creation, and the truth is only supported by those who know the good and act upon it and call to it, and know the evil and avoid it and warn against it" (1).
This research includes an introduction, a preface, five chapters, and a conclusion.
As for the introduction, it includes:
- The importance of the research.
- The research plan.
- The research methodology.
As for the preface, it includes:
- Definition of religious science and its names.

Preface
Definition of Religious Science and its Names:
It is the science concerned with the creeds (maqalat) of disbelieving nations. Creeds generally are divided into two parts:
Part One: Creeds occurring within this Ummah (Nation).
Part Two: Creeds of other nations.
Therefore, when Abu al-Hasan al-Ash'ari wrote about the science of creeds, he authored a book he named "Maqalat al-Islamiyyin" (Creeds of the Muslims) and another book he named "Maqalat Ghayr al-Islamiyyin" (Creeds of Non-Muslims). However, what has become established in the present time is the separation between these two types of creeds, by naming the creeds of non-Muslims as "Religious Science" (Ilm al-Adyan) and the creeds of Muslims as "Sectarian Science" (Ilm al-Firaq).
It is known that in the current era, some sciences have branched out and several sciences have stemmed from them. Among these is the science of creeds (Ilm al-Maqalat), which branched into the following sciences:
1 - Science of Sects (Ilm al-Firaq).
2 - Science of Religions (Ilm al-Adyan).
3 - Science of Contemporary Doctrines (Ilm al-Madhahib al-Mu'asirah) (1).
Religious science has several terminologies, including: History of Religions, Comparative Religion, Creeds (Maqalat), and Religions and Sects (Al-Milal wa Al-Nihal).
Researchers mention (2) that religious science includes three sections:
Section One: History of Religions: This is the descriptive, analytical study specific to each religion individually, which can introduce us to the origin of a religion, the life of its founder... and the reasons for its spread and the types of its development.
Section Two: Foundations and Principles: This section studies the relationships between the foundations on which different religions are based, including creed, worship, law, ethics, and transactions, and the goals they aim for. Among the most important topics in this section is the topic of Divinity.
Section Three: Comparative Religion: It studies the characteristics and features of each religion and balances them against the characteristics and features of other religions (3).

Chapter One: The Legitimacy of Studying Religious Science
One who contemplates the texts of the Holy Quran and the Prophetic Sunnah finds that there is attention given to the aspect of religious science. The texts have mentioned a number of religions and cited aspects of their beliefs, some of which were upon the truth and then were distorted. For example, Judaism, Christianity, Sabianism, idol worship, and others were mentioned. Then the texts clarified their opposition to the truth and their falseness, warned against them, and condemned their followers. We will mention, God willing, the evidence for this.

Section One: Evidence from the Holy Quran:
The mention of religions came in the Quran clearly and extensively. Some verses gathered six of the religions, which is His saying, the Most High: {Indeed, those who have believed and those who were Jews and the Sabeans and the Christians and the Magians and those who associated with Allah - Allah will judge between them on the Day of Resurrection. Indeed Allah is, over all things, Witness.} [Al-Hajj: 17] (1).
Among the verses in which religions and some of their beliefs were mentioned, and the refutation of them, is His saying, the Most High: {Abraham was neither a Jew nor a Christian, but he was one inclining toward truth, a Muslim [submitting to Allah]. And he was not of the polytheists.} [Ali 'Imran: 67] (2).
And His saying, the Most High: {And We sent, following in their footsteps, Jesus, the son of Mary, confirming that which came before him in the Torah; and We gave him the Gospel, in which was guidance and light and confirming that which preceded it of the Torah as guidance and instruction for the righteous.} [Al-Ma'idah: 46] (3).
And His saying, the Most High: {And they did not kill him, nor did they crucify him; but [another] was made to resemble him to them. And indeed, those who differ over it are in doubt about it. They have no knowledge of it except the following of assumption. And they did not kill him, for certain. (157) Rather, Allah raised him to Himself. And ever is Allah Exalted in Might and Wise. (158)} [An-Nisa: 157-158] (4).
To other such verses.

Section Two: Evidence from the Sunnah:
The Sunnah is the second revelation, and in it came mention of religions just as it came in the Holy Quran. The Prophet, peace be upon him, continued to mention these religions and warn against them even at his death, where he, peace be upon him, said: "May the curse of Allah be upon the Jews and the Christians; they took the graves of their prophets as places of worship" (1).
The Prophet, peace be upon him, informed his nation about "the prophets and their nations, and what happened to them and what happened to him with them, as if they were among them" (2).
Therefore, you find in the books of Sunnah, books and chapters talking about the prophets, such as the Book of Stories of the Prophets in Sahih Al-Bukhari.
Evidence for this includes his saying, peace be upon him: "Convey from me even if it is a verse, and narrate from the Children of Israel and there is no harm, and whoever lies about me intentionally, let him take his seat in the Fire" (3), and his saying, peace be upon him: "The Jews split into seventy-one sects or seventy-two sects, and the Christians likewise, and my nation will split into seventy-three sects" (4), and other hadiths.

Section Three: Evidence from the traditions of the Companions and the Predecessors:
The Companions are the generation chosen by Allah to accompany His Prophet, peace be upon him. Therefore, they are the most knowledgeable of people about the intent of Allah and the intent of His Messenger, peace be upon him, and they are the best of generations by the testimony of the Prophet, peace be upon him, for them, where he said: "The best of people are my generation, then those who follow them, then those who follow them" (5).
The positions of the Companions in this regard are many, including: the dialogue of Ja'far bin Abi Talib with the Negus and the delegation of Quraysh (6). And the debate of Abu Bakr, may Allah be pleased with him, with the Jews (7), and the debate of Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, with the Jews (8).
Those are some indications of what the Book of Allah Almighty and the Sunnah of His Prophet, peace be upon him, and the guidance of his Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, contained regarding the mention of false religions and debating their people, which confirms the necessity of paying attention to those religions with the intention of clarifying their deviation and corruption, refuting them, and warning against them and against falling into them.

Chapter Two: Benefits of Studying Religious Science

Section One: Preservation of Islam:
"Since Muhammad, peace be upon him, was the seal of the prophets, and there was no messenger after him, He, Glorified and Exalted, did not cease to establish causes for the renewal of the religion as required for its manifestation, as promised in the Book. Thus, the beauties of faith and its comprehensive aspects are shown through it, and the evils of disbelief and its corruptions are known by it. Among the greatest causes for the manifestation of faith and religion, and the clarification of the truth of the news of the messengers, is the appearance of opponents to it from the people of evident falsehood, as the Most High said: {And thus We have made for every prophet an enemy - devils from mankind and jinn, inspiring to one another decorative speech in delusion. But if your Lord had willed, they would not have done it, so leave them and what they invent. (112) And [it is] so the hearts of those who do not believe in the Hereafter will incline toward it and that they will be satisfied with it and that they will commit that which they are committing. (113) [Say], "Then is it other than Allah I should seek as judge while it is He who has revealed to you the Book explained in detail?" And those to whom We [previously] gave the Scripture know that it is sent down from your Lord in truth, so never be among the doubters. (114) And the word of your Lord has been fulfilled in truth and in justice. None can alter His words, and He is the Hearing, the Knowing. (115)} [Al-An'am: 112-115]. (1) That is because the truth - if denied and opposed with misconceptions - Allah Almighty establishes for it that by which the truth is realized and falsehood is nullified from clear signs, by what He shows of the proofs of truth and its clear evidences, and the corruption of the refutable arguments opposing it" (2).

Section Two: Calling Disbelievers to Islam:
"The first and fundamental goal of studying religions for Muslims is inviting its people to Islam, proceeding from the belief in the obligation of Da'wah (call to Islam). Many texts have been reported commanding Da'wah, including: The saying of the Most High {Invite to the way of your Lord with wisdom and good instruction, and argue with them in a way that is best.} [An-Nahl: 125] (3). And the saying of the Most High: {So to that [religion of Allah] invite, and remain on a right course as you are commanded} [Ash-Shura: 15] (4).

The Prophet, peace be upon him, undertook the call to Allah in compliance with his Lord's command, so he called all people of religions to Islam. He sent his messengers to all the kings of the earth, and debated all categories of those opposing the truth, especially the People of the Scripture. The Most High said: {Say, "O People of the Scripture, come to a word that is equitable between us and you - that we will not worship except Allah and not associate anything with Him and not take one another as lords instead of Allah." But if they turn away, then say, "Bear witness that we are Muslims [submitting to Him]." (64)} [Ali 'Imran: 64] (1)" (2).

Section Three: Refuting the Misconceptions of the People of Religions:
In the history of religions and sects, no religion or sect has been subjected to attempts of distortion and alteration, and raising doubts about it by its adversaries, like the religion of Islam. Its fundamentals and branches have been subjected to a fierce attack since the Prophet, peace be upon him, stood proclaiming the call of truth, conveying the message of his Lord, and calling people to enter the true religion of Allah, and to reject all other religions and sects.
From that time, the people of falsehood declared their war on Islam, and raising doubts and suspicions were the most important reasons and the most effective means for them. The Quran confronted their doubts and refuted them with decisive arguments and proofs. The Most High said: {And they do not come to you with an argument except that We bring you the truth and the best explanation. (33)} [Al-Furqan: 33] (3).
So Allah informs His Messenger that they do not bring an argument or a doubt, nor say a saying opposing the truth, except that We answer them with what is the truth in the matter itself, and clearer, more evident, and more eloquent than their sayings (4).
When the enemies of religion undertook raising doubts and suspicions among Muslims, and began innovating matters that have no basis in religion, and dividing Muslims, Muslim scholars stood up to fulfill Allah's right upon them. They exposed the types of conspiracies that were against Islam, refuted the doubts that the people of religions were spreading among Muslims in their desperate attempts to stop the march of Islam. Thus, Islam triumphed in the field of thought as it triumphed in the field of Jihad with the spear.
Exposing the falseness of falsehood, clarifying the doubts fabricated by the people of falsehood, and refuting them with a firm refutation is a great principle of Islam, and a door of Jihad. Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah said: "The one who refutes the people of innovation is a Mujahid" (5). And it was narrated from Yahya bin Yahya that he said: "Defending the Sunnah is better than Jihad" (6). And Sheikh Bakr Abu Zaid said: "Refuting the people of falsehood, debating them, and arguing with them until their doubt is cut off and their harm is removed from Muslims is a rank among the stations of Jihad with the tongue, and the pen is one of the two tongues" (7). By this, the protection and guarding of the religion is accomplished (8).

Section Four: Lessons and Admonition:
The Quran spoke a lot about the stories of the predecessors. The Most High said: {Thus We relate to you from the news of what has preceded. And We have certainly given you from Us the Message (Dhikr). (99)} [Taha: 99] (1). And He said after speaking about the nations of the predecessors: {Those cities - We relate to you some of their news. And certainly did their messengers come to them with clear proofs} [Al-A'raf: 101] (2).
And Allah - Glory be to Him - commanded His Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, to relate stories to people {So relate the stories that perhaps they will give thought. (176) How evil an example [is that of] the people who denied Our signs and used to wrong themselves.} [Al-A'raf: 176-177] (3).
He, Glory be to Him, described those stories mentioned in the Quran as true stories, saying: {Indeed, this is the true explanation. And there is no deity except Allah.} [Ali 'Imran: 62] (4). That is because of their conformity to reality. And He, Glory be to Him, described those stories as the best of stories, saying: {Indeed, We have sent it down as an Arabic Qur'an that you might understand. (2) We relate to you, [O Muhammad], the best of stories in what We have revealed to you of this Qur'an although you were, before it, among the unaware. (3)} [Yusuf: 2-3] (5).
In the verse is an indication that we must be content regarding the stories of the predecessors with what was mentioned in the Quran, because it is sufficient over all other books (6). And because whatever else is either unreliable books, or doubtful, just as the news of the predecessors became for us a matter of the Unseen which cannot be reached except through a reliable source. The Most High said: {That is from the news of the unseen which We reveal to you, [O Muhammad]. And you were not with them when they cast their pens as to which of them should be responsible for Mary. Nor were you with them when they disputed. (44)} [Ali 'Imran: 44] (7).

Section Five: Clarifying the Path of Criminals:
Among the most important objectives and greatest goals obtained from studying religions is knowing the path of criminals. The Most High said following His speech about the messengers and messages: {And thus do We detail the verses, and [thus] the way of the criminals will become evident.} [Al-An'am: 55] (2).
Allah has detailed in His Book the path of the believers in detail, and the path of the criminals in detail, and the consequence of these in detail, and the consequence of those in detail, and the deeds of these, and the deeds of those, and the allies of these, and the allies of those, and His abandonment of these, and His success granted to those, and the reasons by which He granted success to those, and the reasons by which He abandoned those... And those knowledgeable of Allah, His Book, and His religion knew the path of the believers in detail, and the path of the criminals in detail, so both paths became clear to them, just as the path leading to his destination and the path leading to destruction become clear to the traveler. These are the most knowledgeable of creation, the most beneficial to people, and the most sincere advisor to them, and they are the guides. By this, the Companions excelled over everyone who came after them until the Day of Judgment, for they grew up in the path of misguidance, disbelief, polytheism, and the paths leading to destruction, and they knew them in detail. Then the Messenger came to them, so he brought them out from those darknesses to the path of guidance and Allah's straight path (3).
"And Allah - Glory be to Him - loves that the path of His enemies be known to be avoided and hated, just as He loves that the paths of His allies be known to be loved and followed. In this knowledge are benefits and secrets that none knows but Allah..." (4).
The distinction of the people of truth from the people of falsehood, from the people of desires and innovations, and from the people of false religions and sects, is an issue of utmost importance. The Predecessors (Salaf) - may Allah be pleased with them - were keen on that. Naming the people of truth with titles such as "Ahlus-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah" (People of Sunnah and Community), "Al-Salaf" (The Predecessors), "Ahl al-Hadith" (People of Hadith), and "Ahl al-Athar" (People of Tradition) is only from the aspect of differentiation and clarifying the path of truth from the paths of the people of misguidance. If differentiation from the people of innovation who are from the people of the Qibla (Muslims) is required by Sharia, then differentiation from others among the people of false religions and sects is even more appropriate (5).

Chapter Three: The Sharia Regulations for Studying Religious Science
This science has regulations that must be adhered to, and these regulations are not specific to it, but rather general for every matter intended to be researched. Among these regulations:

Regulation One: Sincerity:
It is that a person seeks the Face of Allah Almighty with his knowledge and action. The Most High said: {So whoever would hope for the meeting with his Lord - let him do righteous work and not associate in the worship of his Lord anyone. (110)} [Al-Kahf: 110]. So the accepted work from the servant is what conforms to the Sharia, intended for the Face of Allah alone (1).
In the authentic Hadith on the authority of Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, say: "Actions are but by intentions, and every man shall have only what he intended" (2).
So the basis for the validity or corruption of actions is the intention. The one standing in defense of the truth, calling to it, and arguing for it is in greater need of sincerity than others. Therefore, the presence of soundness of intention and purpose is a fundamental condition for anyone who engages in the study of religions. His intention in this must be guarding the religion, defending it, guiding people to guidance, and stabilizing them upon it (3), and he should not have any other purpose.
Imam al-Haramayn al-Juwayni said, explaining the etiquettes of debate: "The first thing in it incumbent upon the debater is to intend drawing closer to Allah - Glory be to Him - and seeking His pleasure in complying with His command regarding what He ordered, and to exert his utmost capability in clarification and exposure, to realize the truth and eradicate falsehood. And to fear Allah lest he intends by his debate showing off, seeking status, earning, disputation, contention, and hypocrisy. And to beware of the painful punishment of Allah - Glory be to Him - and his intention should not be triumph over the opponent, and joy in overcoming and subduing, for that is the habit of male livestock, like rams and roosters" (4).

Regulation Two: Knowledge:
Knowledge is among the necessary matters and important regulations for one who engages in religious science. That is because the one engaged in studying religions, if he is not qualified for it, his harm is greater than his benefit. Knowledge is one of the most important conditions that must be met by one who undertakes the function of defending the religion, because knowledge precedes action. The Most High said: {So know, [O Muhammad], that there is no deity except Allah and ask forgiveness for your sin and for the believing men and believing women. And Allah knows your movement and your resting place. (19)} [Muhammad: 19] (1). Imam Al-Bukhari, may Allah have mercy on him, was alert to this, so he titled a chapter for this verse saying: Chapter: Knowledge before speech and action (2).
So knowledge precedes speech and action, because it is a condition for the validity of speech and action, so they are not considered except with it (3).
Among the evidences indicating the condemnation of speaking before knowledge is the saying of the Most High: {And of the people is he who disputes about Allah without knowledge or guidance or an enlightening book (8)} [Al-Hajj: 8] (4). The verse indicated the condemnation of the disputant without knowledge. And the Most High said condemning the People of the Scripture who disputed without knowledge: {O People of the Scripture, why do you argue about Abraham while the Torah and the Gospel were not revealed until after him? Then will you not reason? (65) Here you are - those who have argued about that of which you have [some] knowledge, but why do you argue about that of which you have no knowledge? And Allah knows, while you know not. (66)} [Ali 'Imran: 65-66] (5).
Indeed, we find that Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah sees that he who judges in sects and religions without knowledge or justice is more deserving of the Fire than one who judges between people in wealth, blood, and honor without knowledge or justice. He says: "Since the followers of the prophets are the people of knowledge and justice, the speech of the people of Islam and Sunnah with disbelief and the people of innovation was with knowledge and justice, not with conjecture and what souls desire. For this reason, the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: (Judges are three: two judges in the Fire, and one judge in Paradise. A man who knew the truth and judged by it is in Paradise, and a man who knew the truth and judged contrary to it is in the Fire, and a man who judged for people out of ignorance is in the Fire) (6).

If the one who judges between people in wealth, blood, and honor - if he is not knowledgeable and just - is in the Fire, then how about the one who judges in sects, religions, fundamentals of faith, divine knowledge, and universal landmarks without knowledge or justice" (1).
Knowledge in the field of studying religions includes knowledge of Islam from its primary sources of the Quran and Sunnah, and what explains them from the sayings of the Predecessors, or what helps in understanding them from the instrumental sciences like Arabic language. It also includes knowledge of the misconceptions of the people of religions and sects, and methods of refuting them (2).

Regulation Three: Estimating Benefit and Harm in Studying Religions:
Studying religions and disbelief sects and engaging in them is not without dangers and pitfalls that may harm the one engaged in it, such as the misconceptions of the people of those religions leaving something in his heart. Or he may cause harm to the truth he possesses, if he is weak in refuting the opponents' misconceptions. Studying them can also lead to spreading them and promoting their principles, especially if the refutation is not solid. Therefore, before exposing oneself to studying any religion or sect, the benefit and harm in this study should be estimated. The relied-upon saying in estimating benefit and harm is: the saying of the scholars trusted with their religion (3).

Regulation Four: Returning to Sources:
Returning to the sources of the researched beliefs, quoting texts from them literally, and accuracy in attributing opinions to their owners. As for attributing sayings to people through an incorrect path, or through a path whose correctness is doubted, or through a path whose adherence to truthfulness and justice is unknown, this is from the conjecture which we were forbidden to follow, as the Most High said: {O you who have believed, avoid much [negative] assumption. Indeed, some assumption is sin.} [Al-Hujurat: 12] (4). And Allah - the Exalted - condemned the followers of conjecture and desire, saying: {They follow not except assumption and what [their] souls desire} [An-Najm: 23] (5).
The scholars of the Salaf adhered to this. Here is Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah - may Allah have mercy on him - saying in his refutation of the Christians: "And I mention what they mentioned in their exact words, section by section, and I follow each section with what suits it of answer, branch and root, tying and untying" (6).

Regulation Five: Freedom from Whim (Hawa):
For whim drives one to differ and speak falsehood. Allah the Blessed and Exalted has said: {They follow not except assumption and what [their] souls desire} [An-Najm: 23] (1). And He, the Most High, said: {[And do not follow] desire, as it will lead you astray from the way of Allah.} [Sad: 26] (2).

Regulation Six: Justice and Fairness:
Justice, fairness, and scientific integrity are among the most important qualities that those who differ and dispute should possess, so that no injustice falls on either party. The Most High said: {O you who have believed, be persistently standing firm in justice, witnesses for Allah, even if it be against yourselves or parents and relatives. Whether one is rich or poor, Allah is more worthy of both. So follow not [personal] inclination, lest you not be just.} [An-Nisa: 135] (3). And He, the Most High, said: {And when you speak, be just} [Al-An'am: 152] (4).
Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him, explaining the obligation of justice in every case, and the prohibition of injustice absolutely, said: "It is known that if we speak about those below the Companions, such as kings disputing over the kingdom, and scholars and sheikhs disputing in knowledge and religion, speech must be with knowledge and justice, not with ignorance and injustice. For justice is obligatory for everyone towards everyone in every situation, and injustice is forbidden absolutely, not permissible ever in any situation. The Most High said: {And do not let the hatred of a people prevent you from being just. Be just; that is nearer to righteousness.} [Al-Ma'idah: 8] (5). This verse was revealed because of their hatred for the disbelievers, which is a commanded hatred. If the hatred commanded by Allah prohibits its owner from wronging the one he hates, then how about hating a Muslim" (6).

Regulation Seven: Adhering to Sharia Terminologies:
The issue of controlling terminologies is a matter the Holy Quran alerted the believers to during the era of revelation. Allah forbade the believers from saying {Ra'ina} [Al-Baqarah: 104] and commanded them to say {Unzurna} [Al-Baqarah: 104]. The Most High said: {O you who have believed, say not [to the Messenger], "Ra'ina" but say, "Unzurna"} [Al-Baqarah: 104] (1). That is because the Jews used the word {Ra'ina} [Al-Baqarah: 104] for a corrupt meaning carrying an insult to the Prophet, peace be upon him (2).
The Prophet, peace be upon him, informed about people coming at the end of time who name alcohol by other than its name (3).
The stance of Ahlus-Sunnah regarding the matter of terminologies attributed to prophets or predecessors or opponents is summarized as follows:
1 - Verifying the authenticity of the attribution of the term and its meaning: Sheikh al-Islam said: "What is transmitted from the predecessors and scholars needs knowledge of the confirmation of its wording, and knowledge of its indication, just as what is transmitted from Allah and His Messenger needs that" (4). The matter in this is that knowledge needs authenticated transmission and verified consideration (5).
2 - Following the transmitted terminologies from the Quran and Sunnah: That is because following the wordings of the Quran and Sunnah is better than any other wordings in determining matters of religion, because that leads to agreement with the texts in wording and meaning.
3 - Understanding terminologies: This is by knowing the indication of the term and knowing the intent of the speaker using it. "That is because the indication of speech is only by the language of the speaker and his known habit in his speech, not by a language, habit, and convention invented by other people after the extinction of the era of those whom he addressed with his language and habit (6) as the Most High said: {And We did not send any messenger except [speaking] in the language of his people to state clearly for them} [Ibrahim: 4] (7).

Chapter Four: Methodologies of Researchers in Studying Religious Science in General

Section One: Definition of this Science:
Methodology (Manhaj) linguistically: It is a noun of place from the root 'nahaja' 'yanhaju' 'nahjan', and it is the clear straight path. Al-Jawhari said: "Nahaja the road: He made it clear and distinct. And Nahajahu: He treaded it. And Al-Minhaj: The clear road" (1).
Al-Fairuzabadi said: "Istanhaja the road: It became a clear path (Nahj). And so-and-so Nahaja the way of so-and-so, i.e., treaded his path" (2).
As for its terminological definition: It has been defined by many definitions, including:
1 - It is the way leading to the recognition of truth in sciences, through a set of general rules which dominate the course of the mind and determine its operations, until it reaches a known result.
2 - It is the law or rule that governs any attempt at scientific study in any field.
3 - The scientific rules that the mind follows in its movement to search for the truth in any field of knowledge.
These definitions are singular in meaning even if the expression differs in wording, because their axis is the rules that the researcher follows or that guide the researcher when he wants to research any scientific issue. "Muslim scholars used to express methodology as Principles (Usul) and Rules (Qawa'id)" (3).
Definition of the Science of Research Methodologies in Creed (Aqeedah):
It is a science concerned with studying the evidences of issues that each sect adopts in terms of its sources, method of inference with them, its stance on the sources of others, and its method in studying creed (4).
Regarding the definition of studying religious science, what was said in the definition of the science of research methodologies in creed applies; but it is specific to religions: It is a science concerned with studying the evidences of issues that each religion adopts in terms of its sources, method of inference with them, its stance on the sources of others, and its method in studying religions.

Section Two: Importance of Research Methodologies:
Research methodologies in sciences have great importance, as they are the path leading to any knowledge. Sciences are diverse in their subjects, goals, elements, sources, and research methodologies. Sciences are not defined by their subjects; because subjects help in researching this science or that, and the same goes for goals. Rather, what helps in that is the correct research methodology. To the extent that the research methodology is strong, upright, based on a sound methodological basis, and appropriate for the subject being researched, the results reached will be scientifically valid (1).
Methodology has a great impact and role in the originality of thought and the soundness of deduced ideas, information, theories, and concepts. Unless the methodology of research and thinking is sound or consistent with its direction, the results will not be correct and harmonious. A researcher without a methodology falls into mazes of chaos, confusion, contradiction, and confusion of opinions and results. The research remains confused and sterile, and its deductive outcome is contradictory, without unity in direction and result. Thus, many results that the research could have yielded are lost if it had followed sound research methodological principles and foundations, with clear goals and features, and sound visions (2).
Therefore, it was also necessary to determine for each subject of science and human knowledge its appropriate methodology and special method. So natural sciences have a specific methodology, history has a specific methodology, and each of jurisprudence, creeds, mathematics, philosophy... etc. has its own special methodology within a unified logical scientific framework. That is because methodology preserves for science its order and consistency (3). The progress and retardation of science is dependent on the issue of methodology, revolving with it in existence and non-existence (4).
If the matter is so, it is - also - of great danger to adopt incorrect methodologies. Adopting these methodologies is like the absence of the correct methodology, rather it is more dangerous. If a nation adopts a methodology, believes it to be correct, and adheres to it, while this methodology is misleading and does not lead to the desired truth and required knowledge, then this nation would have entangled itself in great mazes and illusions that deviate it from the desired path and the required goal (5).
As for its importance in the science of creed and religions in particular, it should be known that the issue of choosing the methodology, and the method of understanding and doctrinal interpretation, is not a subjective issue linked to personal inclinations, or subjective perceptions and desires. Rather, the doctrinal methodology is closely linked to Sharia principles, and to the rational concepts of faith that revolve around the center of departure and the base of understanding and thinking (the doctrine of Monotheism), just as it is linked to the subject of research and its nature.

The researcher in the science of creeds, religions, sects, and doctrines finds himself before a great momentum of contradictory opinions, caused by deviating from the straight path and correct methodology. This confirms the saying of Allah Almighty: {Then do they not reflect upon the Qur'an? If it had been from [any] other than Allah, they would have found within it much contradiction (82)} [An-Nisa: 82] (1) and His saying: {But they denied the truth when it came to them, so they are in a confused condition (5)} [Qaf: 5] (2).

Therefore, it was necessary to work on seeking a methodology for research in these sciences that would be a law protecting the Muslim researcher in them from falling into the errors others fall into, and helping him reach results consistent with the Muslim's creed and his view of the universe, man, and life (3).

Section Three: Relationship of this Science to Religious Science:
The science of research methodologies in creed has a close connection with sciences related to belief. Among these sciences is the science of balancing between religions, or what is known as comparative religion, religious science, religions and sects, or the science of creeds, etc.
The science of research methodologies in creed researches the principles from which the people of each religion derived their religion and sayings. Is the origin: Revelation, or something else? Is this revelation distorted, or is it preserved from distortion?... etc. So this science, meaning the science of methodologies, is a basis for knowing religious science, so the researcher in this science cannot do without looking into it (1).

Section Four: Research Methodologies:
Students of the science of creed and religions have multiple methodologies in studying them, depending on the purpose of their study. I will mention here the most prominent of these methodologies:

Requirement One: The Historical Descriptive Method:
In this methodology, authors follow the aspect of historical descriptive narrative presentation, without judging the statements or critiquing them. This type was followed by early scholars, like Abu al-Hasan al-Ash'ari and al-Shahrastani. Also, there are non-Muslims who followed it, such as Ibn Kammuna the Jew, in his book: "Tanqih al-Abhath lil-Milal al-Thalath" (Revision of Inquiries into the Three Faiths).
The truth is that this methodology does not perform the required role of the scholar. Rather, such a methodology may lead to what is called the rapprochement of religions. Therefore, this methodology was "the most abundant of Muslims' methodologies in luck and praise among Western scholars, and with it they are satisfied that scholars of Islam deal with religions" (2). This is a matter not to be rejoiced at. For this reason, we did not find such a methodology among the scholars of Ahlus-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah, but rather it was found among others.

Requirement Two: The Analytical Critical Method:
Analysis is "a process intended to discover the elements of a specific subject for a special purpose" (1). And criticism is intended to present those elements to precise scales, to know their correctness from their corruption. The summary of this methodology is: observing phenomena, then judging them, and discussing them.
The methodology of analysis and criticism is one of the most prominent characteristics that distinguished Muslim scholars, and specifically: the scholars of the Salaf, Ahlus-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah. For the comprehensiveness of the creed with them, the comprehensiveness of verification and criticism came accompanying it. We find this methodology frequently in the books of the Salaf, especially what relates to refutations of sects and groups or those carrying contrary thought. There is no one among the people of innovation and desires who cared for this matter as much as Ahlus-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah. This methodology has benefited Ahlus-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah greatly, for they preserved their creed by it over the ages and succession of centuries, so you find no contradiction or difference among them (2).

Requirement Three: The Comparative Method:
It is a methodology that follows the path of linking multiple subjects, to extract similarities or differences between them, then coming out of that with a judgment supported by the results of the process (3). This methodology in studying beliefs, religions, and sects is a unique methodology characterized by an important result, which is coming out of that comparison with aspects of goodness that implicitly call for the obligation of following it, and discarding falsehood.
Among the features of this methodology: showing points of agreement and disagreement between separated sects and different religions. This in turn leads to correct consideration by the wise people of those sects into the truth that others have. Allah Almighty said: {Say, "O People of the Scripture, come to a word that is equitable between us and you - that we will not worship except Allah and not associate anything with Him and not take one another as lords instead of Allah." But if they turn away, then say, "Bear witness that we are Muslims [submitting to Him]." (64)} [Ali 'Imran: 64] (4).

Requirement Five: The Method of Dialogue, Debate, Refutation, and Argumentation:
Some Muslim scholars in their study of religions followed a defensive direction, confronting missionary campaigns and skepticism that lie in wait for the Islamic society and stir up sedition among Muslims. This direction took the form of live debates between Muslim scholars and disbelievers, from the owners of different religions and sects, and through dialogues and refuting written misconceptions in letters or books. Requirement Six: The Comprehensive Scientific Method in Studying Religions:
The intended meaning of the comprehensive method is the method that includes all previous methodologies, where it cares for presenting what it deals with in study with an honest presentation, along with discussion, comparison, critical analysis, and refuting falsehood and clarifying it. This may take place in the form of a dialogue or debate. This comprehensive methodology is the ideal one in dealing with the study of religions, as describing religions alone does not suffice, and undirected comparison is useless, and criticism and refutations before fulfilling presentation and discussion might involve avoiding honesty and fairness. Whoever tracks the books of Muslims in studying religions finds this comprehensive methodology. Perhaps the best model for this methodology is the book "Al-Jawab Al-Sahih Li Man Baddala Din Al-Masih" (The Correct Answer to Those Who Altered the Religion of Christ) by Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him (3).

Chapter Five: The Methodology of Ahlus-Sunnah in Studying Religious Science
The true methodology in studying religious science is the one that relies on rules and regulations referring to three matters:
1 - Sources of inference in studying religions.
2 - Methodology in inference.
3 - Method of presentation and refutation.
I will mention, God willing, in this chapter the methodology of Ahlus-Sunnah in these matters.

Section One: Sources of Inference for Religious Science according to Ahlus-Sunnah:
The difference in sources leads to a difference in methodologies and results. Two people might research one subject with different sources, and that would be a cause for their difference in results. Hence, determining sources was among the necessary matters. Ahlus-Sunnah agreed on the sources they relied upon in religious studies:
First: The Holy Quran:
The Holy Quran, according to Ahlus-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah, is the first source for knowing truth and falsehood, good and evil. It is the decisive criterion in everything that happens between servants. Holding fast to it has been commanded in more than one place in His Book and by the tongue of His Messenger, peace be upon him. Among that is His saying - the Most High -: {And this [Qur'an] is a Book We have revealed [which is] blessed, so follow it and fear Allah that you may receive mercy. (155)} [Al-An'am: 155] (1). And His saying, the Most High: {Say, "Obey Allah and the Messenger." But if they turn away - then indeed, Allah does not like the disbelievers. (32)} [Ali 'Imran: 32] (2). And His saying, the Most High: {[This is] a Book whose verses are perfected and then presented in detail from [one who is] Wise and Acquainted. (1)} [Hud: 1] (3). And His saying, the Most High: {And thus do We detail the verses, and [thus] the way of the criminals will become evident.} [Al-An'am: 55] (4).
Therefore, the scholars of the Salaf derived their judgments on other religions from the Holy Quran.

Ibn Hazm, may Allah have mercy on him, says: "We - God willing - will mention the description of the modes of transmission that Muslims possess for their Book and their religion, then what they transmitted from their Imams so that the believer and disbeliever, the scholar and the ignorant, may stand upon it visibly, God willing, so they know where the transmission of other religions stands in relation to their transmission" (1).

Second: The Prophetic Sunnah:
The Sunnah is everything that issued from the Prophet, peace be upon him, of saying, action, or approval. It is revelation like the Quran. The Most High said: {Nor does he speak from [his own] inclination. (3) It is not but a revelation revealed. (4)} [An-Najm: 3-4] (2). It is like the Quran in authority. The Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "Verily I have been given the Book and something like it with it..." (3). Based on this, they relied on it in the field of studying religions.

Third: Consensus (Ijma'):
Consensus is a proof by indication of the Quran, Sunnah, and reason. From the Quran is His saying, the Most High: {And whoever opposes the Messenger after guidance has become clear to him and follows other than the way of the believers - We will give him what he has taken and drive him into Hell, and evil it is as a destination. (115)} [An-Nisa: 115] (4).
From the Sunnah is his saying, peace be upon him: "Indeed Allah will not gather my nation - or he said the nation of Muhammad, peace be upon him - on misguidance, and the Hand of Allah is with the congregation (Jama'ah), and whoever deviates, deviates into the Fire" (5).

Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah says: "And Consensus is the third principle relied upon in knowledge and religion" (1). Ahlus-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah do not differentiate in the authority of Consensus between doctrinal matters and others. Also, Consensus repels the probability of error that might occur in speculative matters (Zanniyat), so they rise - thanks to Consensus - to the status of definitive matters (Qat'iyat) (2).
The intent here is to clarify that Consensus is a source of religious knowledge for Ahlus-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah, and that it is relied upon in all chapters of religion, and that includes legal rulings related to people of other religions. So everyone engaged in studying religions should know the places of Consensus in the rulings of the people of religions.

Fourth: Reason (Aql):
Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah says clarifying the concept of reason according to Ahlus-Sunnah: "Reason is a condition for knowing sciences, and the perfection of the righteousness of deeds. By it, knowledge and action are completed, but it is not independent in that" (3). So reason, according to Ahlus-Sunnah, is an innate instinct in humans, by which they can distinguish between truth and falsehood in beliefs, and right and wrong in sayings and actions, but without independence from Revelation. This limitation of the concept of reason indicates that the Salaf cared for reason realizing its great status.
The scholars of Ahlus-Sunnah made reason one of their pillars in studying religions. Here is Ibn Taymiyyah saying, explaining the foundations of his methodology in refuting the Christians: "And we will clarify - God willing - that what the Christians hold of Trinity and Union was not indicated by anything from the Books of God, neither the Gospel nor others. Rather, they indicated the opposite of that. Nor did reason indicate that; rather, explicit reason with the texts of the prophets indicates the opposite of that" (4).

Section Two: Methodology of Inference:
Knowing this methodology is important, as everyone who affiliates with Islam claims to derive their rulings from the Quran and Sunnah and rely on them. The difference in the methodology of inference is the deciding factor between the methodology of Ahlus-Sunnah in dealing with evidences and the methodologies of opponents. Ahlus-Sunnah have methodological rules that distinguish and regulate their methodology in inference. Adherence to these rules spared them the turmoil in methodology and intellectual confusion that accompanied other sects. Among the most important of these rules in the field of studying religions are:

1 - Belief in all texts of the Quran and Sunnah and submitting to them:
The Most High said: {So do you believe in part of the Scripture and disbelieve in part? Then what is the recompense for those who do that among you except disgrace in worldly life; and on the Day of Resurrection they will be sent back to the severest of punishment.} [Al-Baqarah: 85] (1).
Ahlus-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah adhered to this rule in compliance with Allah's command, and precaution against this threat directed to those who believed in part of the Book and disbelieved in part. Sheikh al-Islam, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "Whatever came in the Book and Sunnah, it is obligatory for every believer to believe in it even if he does not understand its meaning" (2).
Ibn Abi Al-Izz said: "So the obligation is complete submission to the Messenger, peace be upon him, compliance with his command, and receiving his report with acceptance and belief, without opposing it with a false imagination we call reasonable, or carrying it as a doubt, or prioritizing men's opinions and the scum of their minds over it. So we single him out with judgment, submission, compliance, and obedience" (3).

2 - The Quran and Sunnah Contain the Fundamentals of Religion:
Ahlus-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah believe that the Quran and Sunnah are sufficient for matters of religion, fundamentals and branches. The Most High said: {And We have sent down to you the Book as clarification for all things and as guidance and mercy and good tidings for the Muslims. (89)} [An-Nahl: 89] (4). And the Most High said: {We have not neglected in the Register a thing.} [Al-An'am: 38] (5).

text:
Even opponents from other nations testified to this perfection and sufficiency in everything. A Jew said to Salman Al-Farisi, may Allah be pleased with him: "Your Prophet, peace be upon him, has taught you everything, even defecation. He said: Yes, indeed he forbade us from facing the Qiblah for defecation or urination" (1). If the Prophet, peace be upon him, taught the nation even defecation, then it is more appropriate that he teach them the universals of this religion. This is what Ahlus-Sunnah firmly believe, unshaken by doubts or tribulations. Their sayings have corroborated this:
Ibn Hazm says: "The Book of Allah Almighty... is the gatherer of the sciences of the ancients and the later ones... He did not neglect anything in it... whoever understands it, it suffices him, and the Sunnahs of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, are the clarification of truth and the light of intellects" (2).
Ibn Taymiyyah says: "Everything people need in their religion, Allah and His Messenger have clarified it with a healing clarification" (3).
The importance of this rule and its great benefit appeared among the scholars of the Salaf in the field of studying religions, especially in comparing Islam with Judaism and Christianity.

3 - The Fundamentals of Religion are One, No Abrogation in Them nor in Reports:
Knowing what accepts abrogation from what does not in the Sharia is a matter of utmost importance, because through it one realizes that abrogation does not entail an impossible matter; rather it is for wisdom and benefit. Also, the lie of one who claims abrogation of what does not accept abrogation in matters of religion is known by it. The reality of the matter is that Sharia is of two types:
First: News (Khabar): This includes everything Allah Almighty informed that will be, or was, or promised us, or narrated to us from the news of past nations, and what He narrated to us from the news of Paradise and Hell, Reckoning, Punishment, Resurrection, Gathering, Creation of Heavens and Earth... as well as what Allah Almighty informed us about His Self, Attributes, and Actions. This and the like of pure news does not accept abrogation (4).
Second: Commands and Prohibitions: Abrogation is permissible in them provided they do not relate to beliefs, mothers of ethics (major moral principles), and fundamentals of worship and transactions, because Sharia is built on preserving these universals (5).

Based on this, speech is directed to the first type when it is said that the fundamentals of heavenly religions are one with no abrogation in them, and to the second type when it is said that Islam abrogates previous religions. The intent here is to clarify that Muslim scholars determined what accepts abrogation from what does not. So what is transmitted from previous prophets is confined to either being of the type that accepts abrogation - so if this contradicts an established ruling in Islam, it is known to be either abrogated or altered - or if something is transmitted contradicting Islamic Sharia from what does not accept abrogation, the falseness of this transmitted matter is known definitively. This approach is only sound for one who proceeds from this rule.

4 - Referring Disputes to the Quran and Sunnah:
The methodology of Ahlus-Sunnah is distinguished by judging by Sharia and seeking judgment from it in what people dispute about in matters of religion, in compliance with the command of Allah Almighty: {And if you disagree over anything, refer it to Allah and the Messenger, if you should believe in Allah and the Last Day. That is the best [way] and best in result. (59)} [An-Nisa: 59] (1).
And out of certainty from them that the Book came to judge between people in what they differed in. The Most High said: {...painful. (63) And We have not revealed to you the Book, [O Muhammad], except for you to make clear to them that wherein they have differed and as guidance and mercy...} [An-Nahl: 64] (2).
Ibn Hazm said: "It is not permissible for a Muslim who acknowledges Monotheism to refer in dispute to other than the Quran and the report from the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, nor to refuse what is found in them. If he does that after the proof is established against him, he is a sinner (Fasiq). As for the one who does it considering exiting their command lawful, and necessitating obedience to someone other than them, he is a disbeliever (Kafir) without doubt to us in that" (3).
The people of truth used this rule with the People of the Scripture, and in this matter they are following the Quran which demanded them to establish their religion and judge by what Allah revealed to them. The Most High said: {O People of the Scripture, you are [standing] on nothing until you uphold [the law of] the Torah, the Gospel, and what has been revealed to you from your Lord.} [Al-Ma'idah: 68] (4). And the Most High said: {And let the People of the Gospel judge by what Allah has revealed therein. And whoever does not judge by what Allah has revealed - then it is those who are the defiantly disobedient. (47)} [Al-Ma'idah: 47] (5).

5 - Warding off Contradiction between Texts of the Quran and Sunnah:
From the starting points of Ahlus-Sunnah's methodology and its postulates is certainty in the impossibility of contradiction between texts of the Quran and Sunnah with each other, as all of it is revelation from Allah. Allah says: {Then do they not reflect upon the Qur'an? If it had been from [any] other than Allah, they would have found within it much contradiction (82)} [An-Nisa: 82] (1). Likewise, the Sunnah is revelation by indication of the Quran, {Nor does he speak from [his own] inclination. (3) It is not but a revelation revealed. (4)} [An-Najm: 3-4] (2).
If someone thinks there is a contradiction between some texts, it is in the understanding of the observer, not in the matter itself. Al-Shatibi said: "Evidences of Sharia do not contradict in the matter itself. Therefore, you will never find two evidences on whose contradiction Muslims agreed, such that suspension was obligatory upon them. But contradiction may occur in the understanding of the observer" (3).
Muslims used this rule in refuting the People of the Scripture, and clarifying the invalidity of their religions, by proving the differences and contradictions present in their books, which indicate that these books have been distorted and altered, and do not represent in any way a revelation sent down from Allah.

6 - Warding off Contradiction between Transmitted Evidences and Rational Evidences:
From the methodological foundations in dealing with evidences according to Ahlus-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah is certainty in the non-contradiction between auditory legal evidences (revelation) and rational evidences. That is because authentic transmission and explicit reason are both legal evidences, and legal evidences all came from Allah, so their contradiction is impossible. Whatever issues are imagined to have a contradiction between reason and transmission, the matter is not devoid of: either it is not from the evident issues known by explicit reason, or the transmission used as evidence is a fabricated lie known to the people of transmission to be a lie, or the transmission is authentic but in a weak indication which the one using it as evidence mistakenly attributed to the Sharia (4). Every explicit sound reason free from misconceptions matches the authentic explicit transmission (5).

Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah said: "I have contemplated that in most of what people disputed about, and I found what contradicted authentic explicit texts to be corrupt misconceptions, known by reason to be invalid. Rather, reason knows the proof of its contradictory which agrees with the Sharia. I contemplated it in major fundamental issues, like issues of Tawhid, Attributes, Predestination, Prophethoods, Hereafter and other than that, and I found what is known by explicit reason was never contradicted by hearing (revelation)" (1).
And Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah said when explaining his methodology in refuting the Christians: "We - and to Allah belongs praise and favor - show that everything they argued with of auditory argument from the Quran, or from books preceding the Quran, or rational, there is no argument for them in any of it. Rather, all books along with the Quran, and reason are arguments against them not for them. Rather, most of what they argue with from texts of prophets, and from rationality is itself an argument against them, and the corruption of their saying appears from it" (2).

7 - Combining Belief in the Ambiguous (Mutashabih) and Acting upon the Clear (Muhkam):
Ahlus-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah took a correct stance regarding the clear and ambiguous, represented in believing in the whole Book, its clear and ambiguous, with acting upon the clear, and believing in the ambiguous (3) until its meaning becomes clear and its indication becomes evident, by contemplating it, continuing to look, or referring it to the clear texts, for texts explain each other (4).
Ahlus-Sunnah used this rule after editing and defining it in this manner in refuting the followers of religions from Jews and Christians, whose habit was following ambiguities and leaving explicit texts, whether in their religions or in what they argued with of Quranic texts for the validity of their religions.

8 - Taking the Apparent Meanings of Texts:
The intended meaning of apparent meanings of texts is what comes to the mind of the addressee of meanings, not the terminological 'Apparent' (Zahir) according to Usul scholars which corresponds to 'Text' (Nass) (5). The intent here is that the apparent meanings of texts are understood by the addressees (6). So they must be taken. The evidence for that is that Allah sent His messengers in the languages of their people. He said: {And We did not send any messenger except [speaking] in the language of his people to state clearly for them} [Ibrahim: 4] (7).

The reason for sending messengers in the languages of their people is to achieve clarification (Tabyin), which is the explanation by which the intended meaning is obtained, the argument is established, and the excuse is cut off. This implies that the prophets came with clear speech understood by those addressed by it. This is the doctrine of the Salaf, so they did not divert texts from their apparent meaning indicated by the Arabic language, and understood them according to the custom of Arabs in speech.

9 - Islam is the Religion Dominant over Other Religions:
Based on this, Islam is the only religion through which the reality of previous religions is known, for it is the source and document for them. Thus He said: {And We have revealed to you, [O Muhammad], the Book in truth, confirming that which preceded it of the Scripture and as a criterion over it.} [Al-Ma'idah: 48] (1).
The Quran is the criterion (Muhaimin), meaning the trusted witness. It witnesses to what is in the books of the People of the Scripture of truth, clarifies what was distorted in them, judges by what Allah confirmed and commanded of their rulings, and abrogates what Allah abrogated. It is a trustee over them in all that (2).
For this reason, Ibn Jarir said: "The Quran is a trustee over the books preceding it. Whatever of them agrees with it is truth, and whatever opposes it is falsehood" (3).

Section Three: Methodology in Presentation and Refutation:
The one who contemplates the books of the Salaf on religions and sects notices that their methodology in presentation, discussion, refutation, and debates was distinguished from other methodologies by characteristics representing rules and regulations in presentation, discussion, refutation, and debate. It is a comprehensive methodology that presents the religions required for study, discusses their principles, analyzes them critically, then refutes the falsehood in them.

First: Presentation and its Characteristics:
Presentation is the form or mold through which the author presents his subject. Styles of presentation vary from author to author, and vary according to the difference in the research subject. Since engaging in religious science is linked to the Muslim's creed as a tool for calling to Allah Almighty and defending the religion, he must make his presentation of religions and sects a presentation that achieves the legal goals for which this science is studied, and be consistent with the Quran's methodology in presenting religions and critiquing them. The observer of Salaf's books finds that their presentation of them is characterized by matters including:
1 - Clarity:
The clarity that characterized the Salaf's methodology in studying religions goes back to their following the Quranic methodology which presents issues of religion in an easy clear style understood by all people. The Most High said: {And We have certainly made the Qur'an easy for remembrance, so is there any who will remember? (17)} [Al-Qamar: 17] (1). And following the methodology of the Prophet, peace be upon him, who used to treat matters with few clear words that run the course of proverbs and wisdom due to fewness of words, abundance of meanings, and clarity. If you contemplate his saying, peace be upon him: "What I forbade you, avoid, and what I commanded you, do of it as much as you can. For those before you were only destroyed by their excessive questioning and their disagreeing with their prophets" (2), the reason for the destruction of previous nations becomes clear to you, which is their excessive questioning and disagreeing with their prophets.
2 - Accuracy and Comprehensiveness in Presentation:
Accuracy and comprehensiveness are requirements of scientific integrity, and it is required in everything presented regardless of the opponent's enmity. Lying against him is not permissible; rather his creed and thoughts are presented as they are in the sources considered by him.

text:
If you contemplate the books of religions and sects, you find that their commitment is a natural result of their belief in the absolute obligation of justice, and their realization that critiquing religions and sects is not valid for them with a deficiency in presenting them, because that allows the opponent to argue against them that the presentation is deficient and the critique is false (1).
Ibn Taymiyyah says in his refutation of the Christians: "And I mention what they mentioned in their exact words, section by section, and I follow each section with what suits it of answer, branch and root, tying and untying" (2).
From that also is not issuing a general judgment on the people of a religion or sect before research and induction are achieved. So they were keen on the comprehensiveness of induction, and not issuing general judgments except after verification and scrutiny. With this accuracy resulting from wide reading and comprehensive induction, the Salaf used to present the beliefs and opinions of the people of religions and sects.
3 - Presentation Suggesting the Legal Ruling:
One of the characteristics of Ahlus-Sunnah's methodology in presenting beliefs and ideas of those opposing Islam is that the legal ruling of the religions being studied appears through the presentation and context in which they cite, and the introductions and starting points they present which suggest the judgment of what will be presented. Also through adherence to legal terms that the Lawgiver applied to the people of religions and sects such as naming them disbelievers and enemies. Then by their keenness to present falsehood in its true form which shows its corruption. Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah said: "As for the false saying, if it is clarified, its clarification shows its corruption" (3).

Second - In Discussion and Refutation:
If some historians of religions and sects sufficed with describing religions and presenting them without clarifying their correct from their corrupt, the scholars of the Salaf described and presented them for the sake of discussion and criticism. Their ability to discuss goes back to the following matters:
1 - Being owners of a clear methodology free from errors, contradictions, and confusion.
2 - The intensity of their enthusiasm, jealousy, and keenness to protect the religion, and their dedication to defending it against all opponents. This enthusiasm and jealousy drove them to engage in discussions and debates with opponents, consequently gaining them experience and knowledge in methods of dialogue and discussion.
3 - Their wide knowledge and high standing in Sharia sciences.

1. See: Muslimu Ahl Al-Kitab wa Atharuhum fi Al-Difa' 'an Al-Qadaya Al-Quraniyyah, Dr. Muhammad Al-Suhaim, p. 2/774, Dar Al-Furqan, First Edition.

They discussed the creeds of nations and their ideas with a discussion based on knowledge and justice, far from provocative emotion, or pretension and desire. Among the pillars of this discussion were critical analysis: scientific comparison far from detestable fanaticism, and solid refutation.
Comparison according to the scholars of the Salaf sometimes occurs between truth and falsehood, such as the comparison between Islam and distorted religions (1). Sometimes it is between two truths, such as the comparison between Islam and Judaism before its distortion and abrogation. And sometimes it is between two falsehoods, such as the comparison between false religions, to show that the disbelief of some and the corruption of their creeds is more severe than others. This is a Quranic methodology. The Most High said: {You will surely find the most intense of the people in animosity toward the believers [to be] the Jews and those who associate others with Allah} [Al-Ma'idah: 82] (2).
The intent of all these comparisons is to clarify the truth and expose falsehood.
The refutation according to the Salaf was distinguished by matters, the most important of which are: strength of refutation, and the tight dismantling of the misconceptions of the people of religions and sects, such that what the people of falsehood think are arguments and proofs cannot stand. Due to the importance of this matter, the Salaf forbade debating with those who are not qualified for debate.
Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah said: "They may forbid arguing and debating if the debater is weak in knowledge of the proof and answering the misconception..." (3).

text:
Chapter Six: Methodologies of those opposing Ahlus-Sunnah in studying religions and critiquing them

Section One: Methodologies of the theologians (Ahl al-Kalam) in studying religious science:
Some innovative sects have a role in this science, which makes it necessary for every researcher in the methodologies of Muslim scholars in studying religious science and sects to address them with study, criticism, and scrutiny to distinguish truth from falsehood. By clarifying the error of the methodologies of those opposing the methodology of Ahlus-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah, the correctness and validity of the methodology of Ahlus-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah becomes clear.
The trends opposing the methodology of Ahlus-Sunnah in studying religions and sects varied, and they are the same trends that opposed the methodology of Ahlus-Sunnah in the fundamentals of religion. Based on the foundations they were built upon and the rules they adopted in inference and understanding texts, they studied religions, although some of these trends did not have clear efforts in studying religions.
For example, Sufism does not have apparent efforts in the field of religious science and sects like some other theological sects; this is due to their isolation from mixing with others. Then their methodology in acquiring knowledge contributes to this, as most Sufis differentiate between knowledge (Ilm) and gnosis (Ma'rifah), claiming that Ma'rifah requires direct connection - meaning without an intermediary between the servant and his Creator - and that the word Ilm is not synonymous with the word Ma'rifah. The meaning is that Sufis did not rely on senses, nor on reason and transmission, but rather relied on states, tastes, and ecstasies which are of the emotional type that are not known by reason but by the heart only, and which are not derived from experience, nor a teacher, nor a book, but from an inner tasting experience, and the knowledge of the heart that knows and witnesses (1).
The isolation of Sufism and their innovation of this methodology, which led them to deny the legal methodology based on transmission and reason, led to their lack of prominence in the field of religious science and sects, since this science is among the sciences that rely on transmission and reason. This trend cannot represent Islam and its methodology in the field of studying religions due to its opposition to the methodology of Ahlus-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah in practice and belief.
As for the philosophers, whether they were pure philosophers or those who mixed philosophy with theological opinions, they were not far from the field of religious science and sects. Philosophy, by the nature of its subject and the scientific environment that was dominated by theological sects, helped philosophers in Islam to delve into the field of religious science and sects.
Religious science and sects according to this trend, which leaned towards the ancient philosophers and adopted their method in establishing unseen truths, researching matters of religion, and defending it, was nothing but a collection of opinions, logical syllogisms, and philosophical justifications. Religious science and sects according to the method of these people is useless in establishing the truth and defending it because it is built on a methodology foreign to the truth, so it should be excluded.
Perhaps the locus of error and danger in this trend can be summarized as follows:
1 - The statements of philosophers regarding Divinity, Prophethood, and the Hereafter clash with the fundamentals of the Islamic religion, where philosophers claim the eternity of the world, that Allah knows universals but not particulars, the resurrection of souls without bodies, and making prophethood of the same genus as dreams.
2 - Reliance on reason in establishing beliefs.

text:
As for the theological trend, it is one of the most important trends because most innovative sects fall under it. The Shia, Maturidis, Kullabis, Mu'tazila, Ash'aris, and other innovative sects that took a rational approach are classified in this trend. Also, this trend is considered one of the trends most interested in religious science and sects. Although each of these categories dealt with establishing the Islamic creed and refuting its opponents according to the perspective it chose, the framework that unites them is the theological methodology.
The Mu'tazila, for example, had efforts in religious science and sects. They had rounds and bouts in confronting the people of religions, sects, and creeds that rarely have a parallel in other theological sects. Their efforts included refuting Jews and Christians, and positive religions like Zoroastrianism, Sabianism, Zoroastrianism, and Brahminism, and against heretics and other opponents within Islam or the sect (1).
The errors of the Mu'tazila in the field of studying religions occurred where religious science and sects were studied in light of their Five Principles. The Mu'tazila believed in the Five Principles (2) and subjected the texts of revelation to these principles, either by interpretation (Ta'wil) or by rejecting the Sunnah which they claimed were Ahad (solitary) hadiths. Then, in light of those principles, they resisted the doctrinal challenges that originated from the people of different religions. Monotheism (Tawhid) or absolute transcendence of Allah, which for the Mu'tazila means "negating the attributes of the Lord," was in confrontation with the saying of multiple gods believed by Christians and Dualists, and anthropomorphism and likening (Tashbih) which was known in Jewish beliefs, and Union (Ittihad) and Incarnation (Hulul) whose source was either Jews or the religions of India like Brahmins and Buddhism (3).
The error into which the Mu'tazila fell is that they confronted an error with an error.
As for the Ash'aris, they presented great efforts in the field of religious science and sects. These efforts were represented in independent works for this science, and in topics included in other sciences, especially in Ilm al-Kalam (Theology) and in the refutations and debates that used to happen between Ash'ari notables and followers of religions, sects, and creeds. Therefore, you find that most books that spoke about sects, creeds, and religions are Ash'ari books. Among them is Al-Baqillani who refuted all categories of religions, sects, and creeds through his book Al-Tamhid. And Al-Juwayni presented many efforts through his theological books like Al-Shamil and Al-Irshad and through his book "Shifa' Al-Ghalil". And Al-Ghazali who wrote in refutation of Christians. Then Al-Shahrastani, the owner of the encyclopedia and circle of knowledge in religions and sects. And Al-Baghdadi, the author of the book Al-Milal wa Al-Nihal. However, they also refuted error with error based on their beliefs in Tawhid, Names and Attributes, and other doctrines. Discussion about clarifying their error in that will come in the next section.

Section Two: The Methodological Foundations for Studying Religions and Sects according to the Theologians and Critiquing them:

First: Sources of Inference according to Opponents:
What is established in this issue among most sects is that the sources of inference are: the same sources as Ahlus-Sunnah. Wasil, the leader of the Mu'tazila, said clarifying the sources of inference: "The truth is known from four aspects: A speaking Book (Quran), an agreed-upon report (Hadith), a rational argument, or a consensus of the Ummah" (1).
It was stated in Sharh Al-Usul Al-Khamsah: That the evidences are four: Argument of reason, the Book, the Sunnah, and Consensus (2). This is according to the Mu'tazila. As for when we come to the Ash'aris, we find them adding another source to the previous four, which is Analogy (Qiyas) (3). But some of them returned Analogy to the Text and Consensus, so evidences were restricted for him to the other four (4).
Theoretically, it is close to the methodology of Ahlus-Sunnah, even if it differed in differentiating between Mutawatir and Ahad hadiths. But if we move to the stance of the people of desires regarding the indication of texts and how to arrange and infer from them, we find it contrary to the methodology of Ahlus-Sunnah; in that they prioritized reason over transmission, opposed Sharia texts with reason, and so on.

Second: Prioritizing Reason over Transmission:
The Mu'tazila, Ash'aris, and other innovators oppose Ahlus-Sunnah in the order of sources of inference and the authority of their indication, as they prioritized reason over transmission. Consequently, it is not valid to infer with an auditory (textual) evidence on any of the theological issues related to the existence of Allah Almighty and His attributes and everything on which the validity of prophethood depends.
Indeed, excess reached some theologians where they tried to weaken the auditory evidence absolutely, whether Quran or Sunnah, in issues of creed, and prioritize rational evidence over it, as Al-Razi did when he said: "Auditory evidences do not provide certainty or decisiveness," claiming that "Verbal evidences are based on speculative premises, and what is based on speculative premises is speculative: so inference by discourse yields only conjecture" (5).
